data.author: Richard Brown

data.text: it doesn't bother me. The saddle is made of steel and leather. Both will biodegrade and return to the earth within 100-200 years. Both materials used no petroleum products to manufacture. Both materials released no toxins while being made. The leather was vegetable-tanned and the steel was forged using traditional blacksmithing. OTOH, the foam/synthetic/plastic saddles will be around for thousands of years and released flourocarbons into the atmosphere during manufacture.
data.author: David J. Syrotiak

data.text: I don't have one yet....but the only reason I will be getting one is the fact its made out of animal skin
data.author: Adam Arfa McCabe

data.text: I do. I like living with nature. I love that animals are given the chance to walk free, eat grass, have their calves by their side and I do eat meat. I don't enjoy killing animals but it is a circumstance that is not possible to avoid if you eat meat. I buy my meat from small farms where the animal is killed basically in the middle of breakfast away from other animals and where every single piece of that animal is being used. This is how we have lived for a million years and I actually have more tolerance with it than with cancer generating, animal killing, ocean polluting, plastics. And my present saddle is actually a Brooks B17 short. I don't know if it is my favourite because I haven't tried it yet.

data.author: Paul Young

data.text: I found the Brooks B17 didn't have enough fore - aft adjustment so I was perched too far back on the saddle. Once the leather softened this equated to my sitbones being right on the metal frame across the rear of the saddle which was really uncomfortable. I've found an improvement on the B17 at Spa Cycles in Harrogate. They have them made (I don't know who by) with a longer parallel section of the rails specifically to alleviate this problem. I've been told the leather is slightly thicker than the Brooks and was slightly apprehensive about the breaking-in process, particularly when the instructions say 500-800km of riding is typical, but the saddle has proved comfortable right from the off. Guess I've just been lucky that it's a good fit anatomically.
data.author: Phil Young

data.text: Selle Anatomica Had for 20+ years. Have on 4 bikes, a brooks B17 on a '95 T400 Cannondale bike. Took forever to break in & this may be TMI, but the breakin did not come without blood sweat & tears. Where as with my SA, I put a new one on in Philly rode 4300 miles X country & though I had issues, none of it was with the saddle. One can find them discounted, used & seconds, which i choose to do & never spend more than a 100$. But hey its highly personal & my suggestion is not to accept discomfort. All the best
data.author: Pat Matson

data.text: I still ride with padded shorts when tis over 20 miles. Do not use any salve or butt lube, havent for decades. Last I checked they charge a 10$ fee for blunting all of the leather edges! Which does need to be done, but one can easily do it themselves by rubbing all the edges with the backside of a knife. All the best

data.author: Gaivenis Mantas

data.text:
I would recommend one that fits your bottom correctly. Sit bone width is super important, and the key metric‚Ä¶so understand this first before you even research, select or test a saddle. Some manufacturers only focus on the upright position as the key factor for saddle selection ie Brooks C15, C17, C19 width sizes (140mm width at 45 deg to 185mm width at 90 deg) https://hincapie.com/ride-with-us/stories-from-the-saddle/how-to-measure-sit-bone-width-for-bike-saddle-size/ For example everyone raves about brooks B17, but they don‚Äôt work for me as i have 11cm sit bones and need narrow saddle (138mm is perfect) so I mainly use Stella Italia superflow saddles on my road. gravel and touring bikes, as I tend to ride in a 35 to 50 deg upright position (leaning forward). On the touring bike its 50deg, so I use the Stelle Italia Well S Gel SMP saddle.
How to Measure Sit Bone Width for Bike Saddle Size - Hincapie
hincapie.com
